description.text:
For the RepRapGuru Prusa I3 V1 and V2

This attaches to the Y-carriage underneath the heatbed. Mount it in the back left corner, pointing towards the back of the printer, with the curved end pointing up (so in case it should sag it will ride over the frame below it). Ziptie it in place.

On the flat arm, attach a zip tie anchor block with adhesive back. Then zip tie the power and thermistor wires coming off of the heated bed, to relieve strain and stop the wires from cracking off due to Y axis movement.

Inspired by thing #1940087. Redesigned in Fusion 360 from scratch.

Updated V4: Shortened up the width of the piece to avoid striking the Y-Axis motor at the back of the travel. Now has >8 mm clearance.

RepRapGuru I3 v2

description.text:
These cheap watt meters are useful for hobby and solar projects.

I wanted to wall mount mine at a below eye level height and was finding the display awkward to read. So this mount allows the unit to be angled better for this use.

This mount can be used as a support on a flat surface, and also has countersunk holes for wall mounting. If used in a place exposed to sun, then the lcd display will be degraded by UV light over time, so I made an optional lid that can swing up to cover the display to hopefully reduce this.

description.text:
QX03b-03 Cable Wrap System

This is an adaptation/remix of Swighton’s “Happy Headphone Cord Winder.” It is larger, and less happy. I had to roughly trace the STL provided by Swighton into Fusion360, but I kept true to the basic aesthetics.
This design accommodates Stereo A/V cords, thicker USB cords commonly used for PRINTERS, AUDIO INTERFACE equipment, and light-duty POWER CORDS.

The hanger fits easily on ½” thinwall, or similar rod.

This design allows easy storage, easy identification, and when the cord is needed for use it can be partially unwrapped so that the QX03b family can be used to take-up cord slack.

This was designed and implemented using PLA. The Hold-Down tabs work okay, but they break if you attempt to insert a cord with too large a diameter.

I have included a STEP file with 4 different manifestations of the QX03b so that you can easily import them into a cad program for modifications and improvements specific to your application. If you are not going to use the Label Tab version (QX03b-03) then print the other models, because that extra Z-Axis is a time vampire!

I employ ReplicatorG for slicing/G-Code/export (.x3g)
I request 2 shells (3 total).
Supports are required for tabs!

TRIPLE PRINT
The design for the triple print fits on a Flash-Forge Creator bed of 6”x9” with room to spare.
The “Sheet” that attaches the three parts into a single file is 0.01 mm thick, and is not translated by ReplicatorG into a printable component, therefore only the hanging cord-wraps are printed.

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

10%

Notes:

220 C Nozzle, 45 C Bed on Blue Painters Tape.

description.text:
Z-axis linear rods for cartesian 3d printers, fits any bed size.
The pictures are on my modified d-bot (www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065)

You need:
4x Ø16 linear rods
2x V-slots 20x40
4x Linear ball bearings LMEK16L
16x Bolts M4x10
4x Bolts M3x10
4x Bolts M3x20
8x M3 nuts
and of course the ordinary M5 and square/t-nuts to fasten to the V-slots (38sets)

When mounting the bearings with the M4 bolts, it's recommended that you first tap the holes, but it´s possible to just screw the bults in place.

title: Ultimate CNC Cut Height Adjustable Desk

description.text: Based off of the very awesome Evil Mad Scientist CNC Workstation Cart (http://www.evilmadscientist.com/2012/cnc-workstation/), I built the ultimate sit/stand desk. After looking into a lot of heigh adjustable desks, I discovered that most height adjustable desks on the market were Conset bases (http://conset.us) with custom tops. Thankfully, a lot of American distributors allow you to buy just the frame. The best price I found was from The Human Solution (http://www.thehumansolution.com/uplift-900-electric-sit-stand-desk-black.html), which came to $589 and free shipping. Same as the EMSL Cart, I used two sheets of Appleply plywood. If you haven't used Appleply before, it is basically America's answer to the ultimate plywood, Baltic Birch. With quality comes a cost. Appleply typically costs around $100 per 4x8 sheet. Learn more at http://www.appleply.com. Also, in my project I decided to include Accuride 24" full extension drawer slides. (http://www.rockler.com/accuride-full-extension-zinc-box-drawer-slides-series-3832-zinc-full-extension-slides). I mounted the cabinet side of the slide 1/4" from the bottom of each slide of the drawer slot, and the slide on the drawer 1/2" from the bottom of the drawer box. Offset 1/8" from the front of drawer, inside wall, and 5/8" from the outside walls. There is a large cord management area in the back of the desk that is isolated from the main desk. This allows me to run two cords up to the desk, one for a power strip, and one ethernet cable. I finished the desk with high gloss polyurethane (multiple coats on the top, sides, and drawer fronts). Other than that, the tool and materials list is identical as the EMSL cart. The drawer boxes, while different sizes, are glued up the exact same way. The only issue with the design is that the bottom of the desk sags about 1/8" just at the front. This isn't a huge deal, as you can see in the photos. This could easily be fixed by gluing the center rail in place, but I like the ability to take the desk apart for easy moving. Learn more about the project here: http://www.adafruit.com/blog/2013/12/20/designing-and-building-the-ultimate-cnc-cut-height-adjustable-desk/

super simplified/minimized spool holder compatible with 70mm wide filament spools.

this holder prints in roughly 3 hours on the Cetus3D

tip: stick 4 rubber blockers, one in each corner, this will stabilise the spool holder.

title: Wider PrintrBot Base and 12mm Z axis, Stylized

description.text:
This is a Widening of the original PrintrBot base that I had an idea for since I am building a larger than stock Printrbot. It is designed to hold 12mm Z rods and LME12UU bearings from VXB. I have stylized the parts I edited to be a bit more edgy. I will be stylizing and uploading the rest of the pieces as I replace them on my machine (which is not complete yet.) the X axis will have slightly less travel to make room for the 12mm hardware, and the Z rods will sit a little bit deeper in the base slightly reducing the Z travel per rod size. I have not yet printed these, if anyone has feedback I would love to hear it. Thank You Brook Drumm for giving us the PrintrBot! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16990
http://www.printrbot.com Oh, this is my first THING! Ready to rock! I will print these this weekend or as soon as I get my Printrbot working. Base with 8mm Z rod uploaded, make sure you get the right one.
Will upload source files at a later time.

print and assemble like a normal PrintrBot, replacing 8mm Z hardware with 12mm versions. You will need more parts from the original Printrbot, as this is only the base and X end pieces. Bearings:
http://www.vxb.com/page/bearings/PROD/12mmLinearMotionSystems/LME12UU Rods:
http://www.vxb.com/Merchant2/merchant.mvc?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=bearings&Product_Code=kit1002&Category_Code=12mmLinearMotionSystems

comments.text:
It's great !
Do you think we can make a printrbot with 12mm X&Y rods too ?
comments.author: Wapata

comments.text: Houston, we have a problem.  I just finished up assembling your parts and ran into a problem with the z-axis motors stalling.  Please see attached photos.  When I lower the x-carriage, the nuts are to close to the bearing causing the nuts to bind in the lead screws.  I measured the delta from top to bottom and it looks like a 3 mm difference.  So, I'd think if we shift the nuts out 1.5 mm on both side that should line up the lead screws.  I'm not sure if you have time but if not could you please post the source so I can mod?  Thanks Morrisgun!!!
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: OK, try the new Test versions, I moved the nuts out 1.5 mm. I will post the full source .blend file soon.
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: Thanks Morrisgunn, I'm printing the Printrbot_Wide_X_Motor_test right now.  The Printrbot_Wide_X_Idler_test has the two hole problem again.  I don't know what it is about thos two holes, I tried to repair with netfabb but it filled in half the holes.  I took some screen shots for you.
comments.author: morrisgunn

comments.text: Never mind, I figured out the problem (calibration grrrr).  Could you please post the source, I'd like to add the adjustable z endstop and modify some of the other files.  Thanks so much for this post.  I finally finished my printrbot+ (200mm X 200mm printable area)  THANK you so much!!!!!
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: I had a similar problem with my original Printrbot, I will try to get you an updated file today. Thanks for doing troubleshooting work on this, I dont have the ability to print it yet.
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: I was able to print out all the parts except for one Printrbot_wide_X_idler, it has non-manifold holes. I tried to repair but couldn't, it just removes the holes. How can I fix these non-manifold holes?
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: sorry about that, I have replaced the file with a completely manifold version. apparently I forgot to merge a few vertices. please try again, and sorry for the inconvenience.
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: Thanks Morrisgunn.  I just tried to slice and print the new file but now it says
comments.author: morrisgunn

comments.text: hey no problem. my printer is not working yet so I have not had a chance to test any models at all. I'll see if i can fix this today. if not, by the end of the weekend.
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: hopefully that has done it.
comments.author: morrisgunn

comments.text: Nope, it still has non-manifold holes.  I opened it up in meshlab and have the problem areas highlighted in green.  It's weird, it's only those two holes.  The one on the other side is fine.  Thank you for all your time and effort, I really appreciate it!!!  This is the last part I need before I can put together my new printrbot.  I'll post pics.
comments.author: morrisgunn

comments.text: try now, sorry we'll get to the bottom of this. for some reason Blender is not showing me any non manifold edges.
comments.author: blw184

comments.text: That still didn't fix it, for some reason those holes were cut in half and had overlapping or self-intersecting facets.  I used netfabb studio to repair. Looks like that fixed it.  Here's all the repaired files, you might want to download and repost them thingiverse.  Thanks for all your help!
comments.author: morrisgunn

comments.text: Any chance of posting the source files? Or alternatively posting the wider base to accommodate the stock 8mm rods? I think quite a few people would be interested in that simple upgrade.
comments.author: pocketscience

comments.text: I use blender. I can import the stl files and further modify them...
comments.author: pocketscience

title: Proteus - an OpenSCAD slope soarer design

description.text:
This is a fast, efficient slope soarer, NOT suitable for beginners.
https://youtu.be/aQ_SdMxxsIY

Note: this Openscad design has a large number of parameters such as sweep, washout, dihedral and many many more. Adjusting these parameters will result in a corresponding outer shell being generated, but may result in some internal structures not being correctly positioned, or possibly puncturing the shell, e.g. increasing the dihedral will cause the ends of the main carbon fiber tube spar to be exposed underneath the wing. These issues are fixable but overall it is a lot of work to get that right for all possible parameters.

Requires OpenSCAD version 2017.01.20 or later.

Update 4 November 2017: Added ProteusFlyingWing.scad. This source file replaces CustomizableFlyingWing.scad and fixes an issue where increasing the noseLen parameter above 90 would cause the hatch to fail to fit properly. Note that fuselages generated with this new scad file will not fit the original hatch and vice versa.

Default specs:
Wing profile: MH-45
Fin profile: NACA symmetrical, 8% thickness
Wingspan: depends on printer max z, 1040 mm for 200 mm, 1160 for 230 mm max z
Root chord: 200 mm
Tip chord: 130 mm
Sweep angle (leading edge): 22 degrees
Washout: 3.5 degrees
Dihedral: 1 degree under each wing (2 degrees total)
Flying weight: 560 g for 1160 mm span version (including 28 g of lead nose weight)

Each wing is printed in 3 pieces, root, tip and fin. The length of the root and tip pieces is set by the printerMaxZ parameter. I have only printed and flown versions where printerMaxZ is set to 230 mm. I have added stls for the case where printerMaxZ is set to 200 mm, for the convenience of people with printers limited to 200 in height, but I have not printed them.

The hatch does not depend on the printerMaxZ parameter, all the other parts do, to some degree.

The total span (including fins) of the Z200 version is 1040 mm.

The only pieces I glue together are the nose to the rear fuselage and the servo guards to the wing (both with thick cyanoacrylate). The wing joints are taped, with fiberglass reinforced tape being used for the most important join between the root wing section and the tip wing section.

The OpenScad code calculates the estimated CG position using code from [email protected]:
http://rcwingcog.a0001.net/V3_testing/?i=1

This CG position is used to place 2 small dimples at the correct balance position under the fuselage.

Vitamins:
500 mm x 5 mm OD Carbon fiber tube spar:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5pcs-5MM-OD-X-3MM-ID-X-600MM-Carbon-fiber-wing-tube-for-airplane-5-3/32242824992.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.dDXTx3

2 mm OD and 3 mm OD carbon fiber rod joiners:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-Carbon-Fiber-Rods-Dia-1mm-2mm-3mm-4mm-5mm-6mm-7mm-8mm-10mm-11mm-12mm/32573564619.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.dDXTx3

Servos:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/hxt900-micro-servo-1-6kg-0-12sec-9g.html

Servo extension leads:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/10cm-servo-lead-extention-jr-26awg-10pcs-bag.html

Elevon linkages (these are too short for mechanical elevon differential - so use electronic differential, 2 pcs required):
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/extreme-3d-1100mm-replacement-control-rod-1-pc.html

Joining root wing section to tip wing section and holding servos in place:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/high-stength-fiber-tape-24mm-x-50m.html

Elevon hinging (both top and bottom surfaces) and joining fins to wing tips:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/1-x-4m-roll-3m-blenderm-tape-hinging-tape-twin-pack.html

Hatch latch:
3M™ Dual Lock™ Reclosable Fasteners (clear not black)

Battery holder bracket mounting:
3M™ Dual Lock™ Reclosable Fasteners (clear not black)

Joining wings to fuselage:
PVC Tape (12mm)

Nose weight:
Lead fishing sinkers (1x 0.5 oz, 2x0.25 oz for the Z230 version)

Weights:
Root wing section (Z230 version): 81g
Tip wing section (Z230 version): 44g
Fin: 18g
Elevon: 11g
Fuselage (nose + rear): 105g
Hatch:17g
Total printed weight (less battery, servos, spar, joiners, tape, etc): 429g

Control throws

These are what I use for the glider version. They are likely to be too large for beginners and for the motorized version.

All measurements relative to the trailing edge at the inner end of the elevons.

Neutral: 1.6 mm of up elevon

Elevator: -4.7 mm to +8 mm

Aileron: - 10.8 to +16.5 mm

In the tx mixer I set the elevator throws to be 45 % and the aileron throws to 100 %.

I set the elevator to 20% exponential and aileron to 45% exponential.

These throws are sufficient to allow a very fast roll, which is why either exponential or dual-rates are needed.

Note, using too much up elevator in a loop will cause the glider to stall at the top of the loop and spin out, so be careful to fly it all the way around the loop to maintain speed (or reduce the maximum elevator throw).

Printer:

Prusa i3 box frame

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

fins, nose and fuselage - 0.2, wings - 0.24

Infill:

S3D Fast Honeycomb, wings 4% at 72% extrusion width, to give 2.9% overall, fuselage 5% at 72% width

Notes:

Extrusion width: 0.4 mm (note infill is 72%, i.e. 0.29 mm), 0.48 mm for Polyflex nose
Perimeters: 1
Top layers: 3
Bottom layers: 3 for all parts except servo guards which have 0 bottom layers.

I use a 0.4mm nozzle.

No fan for the wing sections, except for 50% fan for the last few layers (top solid infill).

All parts printed in PLA except for the nose and servo guards, which I print in Polymakr Polyflex.

I highly recommend using a flexible plastic for the nose piece since this greatly increases the chances that the plane will survive a crash unscathed. This is the case even if a wing tip hits the ground first, since in that case most of the damage occurs when the nose hits and the other wing tries to keep going.
Polyflex is one of the easiest flexible filaments to print and is well worth the cost.

I use Simplify3D and manually add small amounts of support as shown in the screen shots.
I use automatic support for the wing root and then remove any support added to the wing spar tube using S3D's manual editing.
The outer wing panel (ProteusLeftTip) does not need support.
The fins need a small amount of support added manually under the trailing edge, as shown in the screen shot above.

I experienced warping a the trailing edge of the wing root, so I added an oval hold down tab. I cut this off using a cutting disk on a Dremel style rotary tool (important -wear eye protection)!

To avoid warping I use UHU Stick on glass on a heated bed at 70 deg C for the first layer, dropping to 50 C for the rest. Dropping to 50 C is important because otherwise the bottom layers of the print remain too soft, allowing the upper layers to warp them.

I apply the UHU stick as a thin (single sweep) layer with the heated bed at 42 C. The glass needs to be washed clean between each print.

Use glass at least 3 mm thick. Thinner glass will bend under the stress, especially with the wing root part, resulting in a warped print.

Extruder temperature

It is important that the extruder temperature is high enough to give good interlayer bonding. The optimum temperature varies greatly depending on the type of PLA. Low temperature PLA such as Diamond Age and Rigid Ink perform well in the 205 to 210 C range. Higher temp PLA such as the Chinese Wellhan brand need 235 to 240 C (despite the manufacturer's recommendation of 220 C max).
To determine the optimum temperature I print temperature towers customized from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1298948.
Because the PLA quality degrades the longer it is in the hot zone, it is important to print the temperature tower with speeds and layer times similar to the actual wing section. To achieve this, I print 2 towers at the same time, with 10% infill and no fan.

Choose the highest temperature that prints well on the tower, but do not exceed about 245 C since above this temperature the PLA strength will degrade.

Layer height: fins, nose and fuselage - 0.2, wings - 0.24.
Extrusion width: 0.4 for PLA, 0.48 for Polyflex nose.

I printed the servo guards in Polyflex with a 0.2 mm layer height. It is important to print at least 4 at once (2 mirrored in the slicer) to avoid the Polyflex staying too long in the hot end due to the low flow rate, which results in a lumpy surface finish. The dimples in the floor of the servo guards are meant to represent the sweep of the wing so you can tell easily which wing, left or right, a servo guard is shaped for. I use scissors to cut out a notch in the floor for the servo arm when it is in its most forward position and glue them on using thick cyanoacrylate.

I also use thick cyanoacrylate to glue the nose to the rear of the fuselage, with 2 mm carbon fiber rods for alignment. All the other joins are tape, with 3 mm CF rods for the wing joiners.

Cutting carbon fiber

To avoid harmful carbon fiber (CF) dust in the air, I cut CF by hand with a fine hacksaw after spraying both the CF and the saw blade with water from a spray (atomiser) bottle. I start the cut on the under side then saw from the top so it cuts cleanly. I then use wet wet & dry paper to clean up the cut surfaces, and wet paper towels to collect the wet CF residue.

Hatch

The hatch is held to the fuselage at the rear using 3M Dual Lock. Cut 2 pieces the right length to cover the flat at the rear of the hole in the fuselage. DO NOT remove the backing that protects the adhesive just yet! Use a sharp knife to trim off the splines on the outer thirds of the top piece, leaving no more than the central third of the spines (otherwise too much force will be required to remove the hatch). Push the top and bottom pieces together and remove the backing from the top piece only and place the bottom of the bottom piece on the flat in the fuselage. Put the hatch on and push down at the back so the top piece of Dual Lock sticks to the hatch. Remove the hatch and rub down the Dual Lock so it is firmly attached to the hatch. Now remove the remaining backing material and replace the hatch pushing down at the back so the Dual Lock sticks to the fuselage.
If the Dual Lock fails to stick to the fuselage when pulling the hatch off for the first time, spray a little CA glue accelerator on the fuselage and put some CA glue on the bottom of the Duo Lock before replacing the hatch.

Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659724 I decided to design a parametric slope soarer for 3d printing. In slope soaring, low drag and efficiency (the ability to convert height to speed and vice versa) are more important than weight. I therefore chose a moderately thin (9.85%), flying wing airfoil designed by Martin Hepperle, the MH-45, suitable for the Reynolds number range the slope soarer would fly in, of 100000 to 200000, and with good performance at the likely wing loading of around 30 g/dm.

With a relatively thin wing and my desire to be able to use the wing for aerobatics, I used a carbon fiber tube spar. This also means the wings can be taped to the fuselage rather than glued, making it easy to replace damaged parts.

I put the servos under the wing since drag under the wing increases lift, which in turn results in a partially compensating reduction in induced drag. This necessitated printing aerodynamic guards to protect the servos and linkages on landing. Ideally the servos would be in the fuselage and coupled to the elevons by torque rods, but that can wait for a future version.

I was surprised how light and strong the printed parts are when printed with a single perimeter and Simplify3D's Fast Honeycomb infill. The weight of the infill is especially low as a result of specifying an infill extrusion width that is 72% of the perimeter extrusion width, combined with a 4% infill setting.

The design is essentially monocoque, with the tensile strength all in the skin. The infill is so thin that it is somewhat flexible, but still prevents the skin from deforming too much under compression forces. The intent is that the infill acts a bit like the foam in a foam-veneer wing.

I print the perimeters at 72% of the infill printing speed so that the pressure in the extruder stays constant between the perimeters and the infill.

FreeCAD should be able to open files from OpenSCAD , when I set the function import FreeCAD shows the supported format , among them OpenSCAD csg format.
Anyway I printed the fuselage size 200 , front and rear part , the rear part is the motorized version , the Zippy battery 3S 2200 mA desn't fit in the fuselage too tight at least 3 mm more hight and wide are needed to let the battery slides freely in position , second I placed the receiver the fuselage is nearly full there is no room for the ESC.

comments.text:
Hi spinorkit, I printed a motorized version with the remixed fuselage from halfliterpete and it flies great. Thanks for sharing the Proteus with us.
I read somewhere about a larger Proteus v2. How is it coming along?
comments.author: jsj

comments.text:
Many thanks for the tip. Much appreciated, I'm glad your motorized one flies well!
The bigger version is called the Proteus Plus, has a 1.6 m span and flaps. I was just flying it today actually. I am just waiting to get some decent video before publishing it. It's a bit slower, especially with the flaps down, easier to fly and better suited to lighter winds, but a bit more fragile.
I have been experimenting with the design to get it a bit more robust. For quite some time I have been using a fuselage printed completely out of semi-flexible (and therefore indestructible) Polymakr Polyflex.
It uses 2 carbon fiber strips swept back like a V for a spar, along with a 3D printed spar joiner. This joiner takes up quite a bit of room in the middle of the fuselage, so it would need significant changes to the shape and size of the fuselage to fit a battery for a motorized version.
Would you be interested in using it as a glider?
comments.author: jsj

comments.text:
HI there! I would be really interested in the Proteus Plus as I only fly gliders.
I live near the coast in New Zealand and we have fantastic slopes!
Where can I find the prioject?
comments.author: spinorkit

comments.text:
That sounds great, especially the bit about the flaps and the greater wingspan.
As I am living in a flat region, I would again be interested in a motorized version.
If you could manage to incorporate a motor mount and space for a battery into your design it would be awesome.
I am looking forward to see a video of the Plus in action!

comments.text:
After some comments at YouTube I finally finished one with motor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2151371). Its performance is amazing, even with braking propeller (beautiful planes mostly fly well - confirmed!). With the extra weight (motor etc.) it is very stable without yaw wobble discussed before. The question is if not to sacrifice some performance to get more forgiving flight characteristics - stall is an one way ticket to the planet Earth without any warning, which is worse with higher flying weight of motorised version. But you have what you paid for - the glide is perfect and as spinorkit wrote, it is not for beginners.
Thanks for the design!
comments.author: maxad

comments.text:
Thanks for the comments Dan. I have not noticed the stall being severe while slope soaring, despite flying it slowly at times while scratching for lift. Perhaps the yaw wobble has warned me off before I reached it! I have got it into a spin to the ground a few times when pulling too much up elevator in a loop.
Also, I fly with the CG on the dimples, which is fairly well forward I guess.
I am interested in details of the stall(s) you experienced.
Was it during straight and level flight, a turn, or a loop?
Did it tip stall into a spin?
comments.author: maxad

comments.text: I experienced stalls leading to spin several times in level flight after I tried to pull too much, and also at higher speeds in an attempt to loop with insufficient energy. COG was 2 mm (?) to the back, but it flew nicely without single beep at elevator trim so I kept testing. I wanted to shift COG slightly forward, which I think would surely help (maybe at a cost of slightly worse glide), but the last spin was unintentional and shifted COG to values that could not be measured anymore :-). I was really surprised by the performance it showed in my configuration. I want to try the original slope version (which is lighter by at least 100g) and a folding prop (which needs some mod to limit flapping blades to avoid their collision with wing trailing edges) for motor version.
comments.author: spinorkit

comments.text: I am also interested in making a version with a folding prop. I have not yet found a suitably small folding prop/motor combination so I would be interested to know what you decide on, not being expert in matching electric motors to props. When I get time I am aiming to do a version of the fuselage with a hollow tube motor mount with air vents near the nose, and at the rear of the tube, for cooling the battery and ESC.
comments.author: maxad

comments.text:
Regarding the drive train, I decided to use what I have found in a drawer... 1400 kV motor (http://www.dys.hk/ProductShow.asp?ID=30) and 8x6 prop (https://hobbyking.com/en_us/folding-propeller-w-hub-35mm-3mm-shaft-8x6-2pcs.html). The actual spinner diameter is only 31.5mm, but still a bit big for the motor and motor mount. I had to protect the wing with this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2449877 (it works better than it looks...). ESC is YEP 30A, set up for automatic timing and hard brake, battery is Zippy 1300mAh. This all gives 760 g static thrust at 11200 RPM and 19A (this is really low, but Agilent current probe said that). I tried not to bother with cooling holes (except four small holes in the motor mount that fit holes in the motor back plate) and surprisingly both the ESC and battery stayed just slightly warm in a hot day, partly due to reasonable motor/glide time proportion. Total flying weight was 685g, which I think could be reduced - e.g. by the use of weaker and lighter drive components.
I think something like this https://hobbyking.com/en_us/black-widow-2208-18a-10d-ccw-1800kv.html (there are versions with different kV available) would be OK since the ESC cooling is solved perfectly. It is not easy to find a prop spinner that small (such as https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1-1-28mm-Aluminum-Folding-Prop-Spinner-3-0mm-Shaft-With-Adaptor-5mm-RC-Airplane-Parts/32712878597.html). Propeller blades should be chosen according to motor kV - both higher kV motors and corresponding bigger props are heavier but more efficient and vice versa. Since Proteus loves speed, props with high pitch are necessary.
A propos, after shifting CG close to the position marked on the fuselage, low speed stalls with spins disappeared, replaced with yaw wobble - exactly as you anticipated. It still needs to be really steered and I was able to do some high-speed stalls, but it is OK - it is a plane, not a Barbie accessory :-)
comments.author: spinorkit

comments.text:
Dan,I haven't done the stability analysis in xflr5 yet but I think increasing the sweep from 22 to 25 deg and reducing the taper so that
tipChord = 0.8*rootChord; should result in more stability and less propensity for tip stalls. This would also increase the area of the fins.
comments.author: maxad

comments.text: Thanks for the detailed info, Kit. I have already tried to fiddle with the parameters you mentioned - and some others. I left my wings detachable (it is fine if everything incl. Tx fits small backpack) and wanted to make the connection between the wing and fuselage more rigid, so I wanted to use bigger diameter spar for next print. However, after changing the spar diameter to 7mm the spar tube intersects with servo lead tube. I have found that it was not just due to the diameter increase, but also the servo lead tube shifted towards the spar: https://photos.app.goo.gl/9pZvvUglZ0l0zbcw1. I admit I was not able to figure out what happened in CAD data, I did not change anything but the spar dia. In addition, when I went through the stl in SkechUp, I noticed that the spar tube support is splitted and does not touch completely the inner wing surface: https://photos.app.goo.gl/3P2CUJTY4SLMp7do1 https://photos.app.goo.gl/WccpgBF4TUxZrejH2 (this is a slicer output for original STL downloaded from here). Was that done on purpose? It makes the fuselage-wing connection a bit wobbly if not glued together. Thanks for your help or suggestions.
comments.author: spinorkit

comments.text:
Yes Dan, you found a bug there, no doubt one of many! The spar/servo lead guide separation should scale better with sparD if you change the line around 1478 from:
overSparAngle = atan((servoLeadDepth-sparD+bendPosFromServo*tan(dihedral)+1.5)/bendPosFromServo);
to:
"overSparAngle = atan((sparD/2+bendPosFromServo

Wow, a printer that size certainly gives you lots of options and thus raises lot of questions!

Longer spans necessitate wing joiners for transport.

If you scale them up, I'll print it.  I'm thinking I should print the 230mm version first and then do the larger one.  A friend of mine that used to build sailplanes moved to New Zealand.  I'll send him the 230mm version when I make the bigger version.
comments.author: spinorkit

comments.text:
I have some ideas for a scheme for changing the design to use swept carbon strip spars instead of a straight carbon tube spar. This will remove many of the constraints on the design parameters and should make it possible to have spans of 2 m or more and higher aspect ratios.
There is quite a lot of work involved and I have little spare time, so it would definitely be worth practicing with the 230 version in the meantime.
Shipping the 230 version in pieces in the "untaped" state is certainly very practical.

comments.author: Carletto73

comments.text: Wonderful job.  I'm so glad to see some honestly well-designed planes like this hitting Thingiverse.  I'm working on some designs myself but am 3D CAD challenged so I appreciate the thought into developing airframes like this.
comments.author: MacGyverDad

comments.text:
Thanks for your encouraging words! I learned a lot about OpenSCAD while doing this. Unfortunately, most of the code was written quick and rough before I knew better ways to do it, so there is a lot to improve!
While I find OpenSCAD a bit painful to use for a project this large, I have yet to master any other CAD tool well enough to do this sort of thing. Writing code suits the way I think and gives me a sense of being in control.
I built my printer 3 years ago and was skeptical about printing airframes with it. I was expecting a million pieces after the first heavy landing, but while it can't match the robustness of EPO foam, it flies much better than most foam wings and has survived some bad crashes with either no damage or minor damage requiring 5 minute repairs with cyano and/or tape.
comments.author: MacGyverDad

title: I Pots Sefl Wathering and growing pots
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: 03.02.2017

Bonjour,

Ceci est mon premier gros projet qui allie Mecanique, Electronique et de l'eau XD

Donc, le IPOTS est un pot automatique qui arrosera et régulera sa lumière avec une grow LED 10W votre plante en fonction des paramètre utiliser dans l’application Blynk crée a cette effect.

Pour l'impression de la pièce Eau, il faudra des paramètre spécial pour qu'elle soit étanche.
j'ai mis 4 couche dessu, dessous et périmètre. En plus j'ai passé l'extrusion multiplier a 1 au lieux de 0.9 sous Simplify3D

Update:

Nuage.stl -> est mise a jour pour un écoulement plus efficasse.

Ipots.ino -> Ajout d'un bite d'erreur quand il y a plus d'eau

Plant de câblage -> OK

Test Growing led -> OK

Mise a l'heur automatique -> OK

Régulation de l'humiditer de la terre -> OK

A suivre:

Création d'une nouvelle version du pot off-line et utilisation d'une électrovanne pour l'eau se qui fait que l'eau sera au dessus de la plante (plus facile a remplir et contrôlé le niveau)

Hello,

This is my first big project that combines Mecanique, Electronics and Water XD

So the IPOTS is an automatic pot that will water and regulate its light with a 10W LED growth your plant according to the parameter use in the Blynk application creates an effect of this.

For printing the room Water, it will require the special setting for it to be waterproof.
I put 4 layers on top, bottom and perimeter. In addition I spent the extrusion multiplier a 1 at the places of 0.9 under Simplify3D

Update:

Cloud.stl is updated for a more efficient flow.

Ipots.ino -> Adding an error bite when there is no more water

Wiring Plant -> OK

Test Growing led -> OK

Automatic time setting of the module -> OK

Control of the moisture of the ground -> OK

To be continued:

Creation of a new version of the pot off-line and use of a solenoid valve for the water which makes that the water will be at the top of the plant (easier to fill and checked the level)

description.text:
An updated print cooling duct for the Anet A8 e3d v6 Bowden Print Carriage REDUX carriage.

NOTE This may work with clones, though was designed using an authentic E3D V6 hotend and heating block.

UPDATE 2/15/17 There is a new version added which allows an additional 4mm in width to allow clearance for the wires running to the heating cartridge. Some users had issues with the cooling duct melting around the wires, and this updated version has several prints and many hours with no signs of warping.

Credit is due to Daniel Levinson. for expanding and testing the updated design.

author: Narvesh

description.text:
The standard mount base for the Nimble.
This adapter should be the basis of any adapter for the Nimble. It holds all the shapes that will lock the Nimble to the hot end, ensuring concentricity and positioning are spot on.

When using the basic adapter or a variant of it, make sure you install the PTFE tube correctly. Most hot ends have a PTFE tube at least partway into the hot end.
The adapter has a 3 mm hole in the center. This is for the PTFE tube. It is too small on purpose. This allows you to drill it up to the correct size for your PTFE tube. We have seen a bit of variation in diameters of tubing so decided to leave it up to you to get the final sizing correct. Drill the hole to the diameter of your PTFE tube and then proceed.
Look at the image and follow the steps.
Step 1. Mount the hot end with a long enough piece of PTFE so that it sticks out above the adapter.
Step 2. Slide the tube up through the adapter.
Step 3. After you have mounted the hot end and just before you mount the Nimble, slice off the tube flush with the top of the adapter.
Result. You now have the perfect length of PTFE tubing in your hot end. By mounting the Nimble you also lock the tube into place.

Edit 1:
The model is updated.
The hole for the PTFE tubing is slightly changed as well. It now is 3.5 mm and has a keyhole shape that will allow you to push the PTFE lock collar on the V6 down, without full disassembly. Use a thin pin, insert it in the smaller part of the hole to push the lock collar on the V6 down. You can now pull out the PTFE tube.

Edit 2:
We replaced the Basic adapter with a more simple shape. This shape is shown to be just as accurate in locking in the position of the Nimble. Included are many formats so you can find the one to use in your CAD package.

The Nimble Extruder
With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lighest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and is installable in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available at: https://zesty.tech
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/00mB6e8Brfs

A nice germinator cover for Mason Jar to sprout your own seeds.

To make this germinator cover, you need to use your print parameter to ajust the fill and perimeters as shown. A perimeter of 5 and a rectilinear fill 0.3 did a nice job. This is my first project :-)
It was made in an afternoon in 3 iterations at EchoFab.org in Montreal in collaboration with Marc Olivier.
Using a very simple design a cylinder and adapting the parameters. The first iteration used a desing made with OpenSCAD. But after printing the first one and checking various projects already made at EchoLab, we did tried to use a simpler design made with SketchUp and played with perimeter and fill on the Ultimaker.
On the second iteration a height of 1mm was tested.
On the third iteration a height of 2mm was tested and the result was more than good enough to use it at home and start sprouting :-) Thanks to Marc Olivier at EchoFab.org for his inputs, advice, knowledge of all the paratemers and training.

author: zuendler92

description.text:
Adapter to fit the Nimble to a Cetus 3d printer.
This has been a very nice collaborative effort together with Michael S and others. This adapter replaces the complete stepper on the print head and as you can see, reduces the weight to 1/3rd approximately.

It consists of a base plate, Nimble lock in plate and a Cable PCB cover. After you print everything, mount the Nimble, the lock-in plate and the base together using 2 screws for the Nimble, you will need the M3x35 supplied with the Nimble and add an M3x40 screw.The nuts go underneath in nut receptacles.

Then mount the whole assembly to the Cetus3D base plate. The screws you need here are M3 x 10. These screws are usually surplus supplied with the Cetus3d printer.
You can then mount the PCB board with the original screws and click the cable cover in place.
The base plate also has 2 holes to mount the fan on. The wires for the fan can be placed in the cable channel at the back of the base, holes are provided for tie-wraps.

The Nimble Extruder
With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and is installable in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available at: https://zesty.tech

comments.text: do you have any video of the nimble on the cetus... i have 2 extended versions (MK1 and MK2) would love to switch to nimble extruders as the only issue i have had with the cetus is the extruder feed.
comments.author: mhjorleifsson

comments.text:
No, I don't. To be honest, I don't if anybody has actually mounted the Nimble on a Cetus. I will ask on our dedicated chat if somebody has but have not heard of it.
The main issue is the repositioning of the extruder stepper, the wiring becomes a problem. The cabling for the Cetus is so integrated that the only way to reposition the stepper is to make a completely new cable. As I don't have access to a Cetus, I cannot check to see if it can be done properly as I have not seen the control board.
comments.author: mhjorleifsson

comments.text:
Nice spool.
Here are my observations. The center hub is 60mm and the opening in the holder for the $5 filament is 50mm so you have to remove the holder that comes with the $5 filament.
The overall diameter looks like 120mm. It really needs to be a fair amount larger to keep the filament from jumping over the sides/edge and tangling.
I am going to make add on sides to help keep the filament on the spool.
comments.author: wirlybird

comments.text:
You must not have printed the spool holder yet? You do not have to remove the $5 filament bobbin to use this spool holder. It's designed so the threads on the male hub go through the bobbin and the shoulders then clamp on the bobbin to keep it from spinning. As far as the flange OD I have never once had the filament snag or hang up. If you are concerned about this you can use this spool it's the same thing but with a larger flange diameter and it's a quarter turn design.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2194890
comments.author: wirlybird

Hi all, I remixed this great robot. Since I used MG90s so metalgear servo's some files needed to be modified.

Electronics: Chinese board with
PCA9685 16 Channel 12 bit PWM servocontroller, DFrobot Bluno Beetle with bluetooth BLE and a HC04 PING sensor. 4x AAA directly powering the Bluno, 7.4V 1500mAh lipo pack with 6V UBEC to make the power for the 13x MG90s metal geared servo's

The Android App is also included. It is however not required, when there is no connection then the robot moves autonomous.

Wiring can be found in the sketch as well as how things work with the legs moving in groups. I did put a switch in between the power for both servo's and Bluno, this is not in the wiring overview.

Make sure your phone supports BLE bluetooth.

EDIT 17th February 2017: I added little rubber feet to the legs (see the pictures). These are silicone connector protection caps available from Aliexpress.com (8mm types) and work great.

Also an important note: keep the servo wiring as far away from the Bluetooth Bluno board since it disturbs the communication. Look at the newly added picture how I kept the wiring seperated.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

40% is not rewquired I wanted to make it strong though

remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini Glass Bed Mounting Bracket

title: Mini Glass Bed Holder for 140mm Glass

description.text:
This is a remix of the Glass Bed Mounting bracket to fit a 140mm by 140mm piece of borcilicate glass. This actaully extends your bed so that you can set your X and Y bed dimensions to 130 to give you a little more printing real-estate.

There are two brackets. One for the front and one for the back. The one for the front has a cutout for the hot end homing position. I found that with the original design my Mini tried to home on top of the plastic and would get my print head stuck causing all kinds of problems.

I printed this at 0.2 with 50% infill using TechOrbits ABS Red temp 240 bed 80.

author: deweycox

print_settings.Notes:: Intention to print with bronzefill

description.text:
A Cthulhu statuette from "The Call of Cthulhu" by Howard Philips Lovecraft.

Made with intention of printing with bronzefill and aging it with salt and vinegar mixture to produce a patina.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Intention to print with bronzefill

1. Print with bronzefill
  2. Polish the surface using rock tumbler filled with small brass screws, or using sanding (optional - I actually skipped that step to get effects like in the picture - cthulhu looks better if not shiny imho).
  3. Age the statuette using salt and vinegar vapors to create greenish patina:
    • mix salt with vinegar
    • pour a little to a pot, so the bottom is covered
    • put the bronzefill figurine in the pot
    • cover the pot with a lid - rusting will begin instantly

description.text:
This is a remix of the Glass Bed Mounting bracket to fit a 140mm by 140mm piece of borcilicate glass. This actually extends your bed so that you can set your X and Y bed dimensions to 130 to give you a little more printing real-estate. It provides access to the adjustment screws so that you do not have to remove the glass to level your bed.

There are two brackets. One for the front and one for the back. The one for the front has a cutout for the hot end homing position. I found that with the original design my Mini tried to home on top of the plastic and would get my print head stuck causing all kinds of problems.

I printed this at 0.2 with 50% infill using TechOrbits ABS Red temp 240 bed 80.

I needed a hook for my wire shelf in my workshop to hang things that just don't do well in containers so I designed this. For standard wire shelving, use 7 mm as the inner diameter and 20 or 21 for a maximum width for the hook. The rest is up to you has to what you want to do.

This was my first try at writing a parametric design in openSCAD. Please feel free to comment on the design. I plan on making a change with version 2 which will allow the choice of rectangular or circular bottom hook.

As in the pictures.
The hooks are 8x8mm big, maybe i'll change that later.

Soooooo, at our hackerspace ( http://nurdspace.nl/ ) we received this toolpanel with 8.75m2 holes in it, totally hookless. The donater went on to explain a bit about the hooks and their attachment of their hooks. About half an hour later I was printing the first tryout hooks and after some finetuning of the model, I had really usable hooks. What you get here are the final iterations of each type of hook I made, as I make them. haakje-bla is the hook
6mm-gaatje is a 6mm big hole for screwdrivers etc
bakhaak-bla is a hook for that normal container you put on toolpanels :) (wish i knew their name, will get a photo uploaded later) If you have such a toolpanel and use my hooks, please feel free to post hookrequests :)

Simple Prop-Protector, print two of them and screw them together with your top-plate. They will be a bit in the way of the camera. If that disturbs you, just put a small drop of hot glue to the edge of the top plate. That will lift the protector a bit.

Shim to print with glass on your QIDI printer. This should pressure fit your printer where your limit switch is. What you want is to place your glass and be able to print on it without the nozzles hitting it. You can print this shim (modify if needed), place in your platform and then adjust and calibrate your platform in order to print correctly on your new glass surface. After moving to glass I do not plan on ever going back. You may have to increase bed temp ever so slightly to account for the extra glass thickess and proper heat transfer to part. You will have to play with it and get your printer to where you want it. This should be a quick and easy print.

title: GEEETech i3B (METAL version): Single Extruder FAN & LED (V3 with 3DTouch)

description.text:
Hi,
now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic parts instead of original printer ones.
Quite immediately I’ve ordered the upgrade kit in order to improve the stability and the quality of my, already not-so-bad printer, unfortunately the customization I’ve designed for the plastic version of this printer cannot be used on the metal one, so I’ve started designing a completely new customization, starting with all lesson learned from my original customization!
One, main, lesson learned was to decouple all contact, in order to enable easy mounting, maintenance and upgrade!
Here the Mono Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization in his second iteration version!
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!

From the V2 this V3 have “only” add the place for 3DTouch sensor that GEEETech is released to implement ABL…and to create the correct space, in the same identical position described in the GEEETech 3DTouch installing documentation, I’ve rotate 45° the FAN.

As usual in all my design I’ve split all in order to have an easy print of each, and also an easy mounting after print!

PS: after the installation of this customization is a good Idea to re-execute the PID Autotest… I’ve do two time, one with fan power off and one with fan power on, and both was really different from the same test executed just couple hours before!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

comments.text:
What filter material are you thinking of using?
I've tried several things, with only modest success.
For example, I used activated carbon in http://www.instructables.com/id/Making-Your-Mini-Laser-Engraver-Safer-and-Better/ , but it still lets some odor through. Smells like a distant campfire when cutting wood. It certainly collects a lot of airborne crud -- the filter gets brown in just a few hours of laser cutting.
I'm looking at a much larger-scale filter system as I am upgrading a 2.5W 50x40cm unit now....

Print speed - whatever you like.

This is for the remaining tools (clipper and spanner) and like the other side, uses existing holes in the Perspex.

NOTE: In order to use these holes, you have to unmount the power supply and one screw needs to go in the other way round, so that the cross head is behind the power supply, so the power supply can fit back in place.

When you put the power supply back on, put 2 washers on each of the 3 screws that secure it, between the acrylic and the supply (like spacers) so it sits evenly. This is actually better, because it allows the power supply to not get too hot, and the heat won't transfer to the plastic frame, affecting your prints.

Cura settings:
Print upsidown. No support needed.

Tool holder for the other side is here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2072360

comments.text: You can also mount this on the bottom 2 screws for the power supply to not have to use washers

author: cleytie

description.text:
This thing was made with TinkerCAD. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lgfmwBLiMmX-fleur-de-lis-coins

This was my first try using TinkerCAD, pretty cool.

These coins were made for my copy of Rococo, which while perfect, can use some material upgrades. (1) is any sort of tile holder for the fabrics. But (2) is more VP tokens during scoring. These tokens are hollow and sized to hold a U.S.A. Penny -- don't tell the Treasury about me please.

I printed at 0.05mm resolution, this supports the detail of the edge; but also, I think, the number of layers needed to do the bridging at the top of the coin. You may have success at 0.1mm, but I think 0.20mm will likely fail.

You need to ensure that the bridging layer (z=2.25mm) is generated correctly in your slicer. I needed to reduce perimeters to 2 in order to have slic3r work correctly (otherwise it seems to want to bridge a too small inner diameter, I am using version 1.31.6-prusa3d).

You should add z-color pauses at 0.35mm, 2.25mm, and 2.55mm. The first and last are actual color changes. For the middle one, you add pennies to each token. Make sure you eye-check that they are sitting flush or lower inside the area.

The pennies add a subtle but welcome weight to the tokens. I found the edge detailing comes out rough to the touch (and I'm not going to sand 80 tokens), but it does look nice.

The original game came with this distribution: 20VPx12, 10VPx8, 5VPx8, 2VPx8, 1VPx12

I have printed these quantities: 20VPx12, 10VPx16, 5VPx16, 2VPx16, 1VPx20

The TinkerCAD design is easy to edit, try making your own designs!
Wrench to assemble and disassemble RST fork, I was using it for old RST Mozo Pro. Print wit 30% infil.

author: Langelus

description.text:
This is a printable mount for the widely available T95N mini media player. I was asked to design something that would allow the player to be mounted under a shelf and this is what I came up with. The base is provided in two mirrored versions that allow the unit to be mounted up or down depending on your needs. I have provide three top designs which clip onto the base.

You will need support for the clip holes and the oval for the IR receiver and power light. On the top you may require support for the clips.

Due to the nature of printing PLA you will need to be careful installing the top to avoid breaking the tabs. Locate one pair first and then slowly angle in the other two. Once the last clips are in place this provides a snug enclosure with easy access to all connections.

Edit: Added an untested mount to 100mm VESA plate. It might be useful to mount behind a monitor.

title: RC Car Active Suspension Shocktower on Schumacher Mi1

description.text: This is an active suspension system for RC Racing Fun.

This is an active suspension system that uses an Atmel 328p and an Accelerometer to determine the G-Force and position of your car. It counters the G-Force with servo power to give you more traction. This is the most fun I've had with RC ever. I'm hoping that this system may eventually find it's way into other RC cars. I'm using a board that I made for this called the California Roll or CA-Roll. I'm selling it at eeltronix.com.

comments.text: Glad to see your still active on this. Dont give up on this project, alot of other rc company for example losi and traxxas are coming with ative control for their cars to help beginner.  Have you thought about incorporating throttle input for traction control?
comments.author: Speedo99

comments.text: Hi, have you had any advancements with your project? I'm very inspired to do this on a Revo, would be interesting to see where it takes me. With this, you can exclude the Anti Roll Bars, and most of the suspension setup, because it can be done with the digital interface. A question tho, why not stepper motor and linear bearings? how quick the response has to be from the hardware to actually make this work?
comments.author: mikeylama

comments.text:
Hi Mikeylama,
I've done some modifications. I'm prototyping with a different chip. But I've been busy with other stuff and there hasn't been much interest in the project so far (a grand total of 9 requests and one board sold). I showed it to some hard core on-road RC guys and they just blew it off. I guess it's against the ROAR rules to use any type of electronic suspension assistance.
comments.author: mikeylama

comments.text: okay, that makes sense what you are telling. However, every race organization banned the active suspension because of the unfair advantage they represent. Have you had a thought about developing an off-road version? also, have you developed the active suspension for the front as well? with pushrods you could bring the weight down closer to the CoG of the car, what would tremendously improve the stability and the agility of the car. Have you made different trials with servo types? What speed/strength was adequate?  Any chance for a track video? perhaps a comparison on track? I really like this project, I'll definitely going to go ahead with this build in the future.

author: hostedathome

title: Filament Sample Spool for Small Build-Volume Printers

description.text:
I've noticed that sample filament tends to come packaged in one of two sizes -- small / tight coils, and considerably larger coils. This presents a problem for me, since my printer (a Kodama Trinus) has a fairly small build volume -- so I can't directly print a spool large enough for the small coils, much less the larger ones.

So I came up with this design, centered on a hub just small enough to print on my Trinus, and with filament-holding "forks" of various lengths. Use a bit of "super glue," and a few minutes' drying time later you've got a customized spool.

Spool w/ short forks -- holds filament on a 12 cm / 4-3/4" diameter
Spool w/ long forks -- holds filament on a 15 cm / 6" diameter

author: rsgeek

description.text: This is a filament guide to make easy and quick filament changes on Anet A8. This along with the instructions in the word document allow one to change filament in the middle of a print for printing multiple colors or materials. It uses and enhances the features of the Repetier Host to accomplish this

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

grid, 20%

Notes:

Be sure to read the PDF!!
Use 30% grid support in Cura Engine in Repetier Host. This leads to least warp of the plate which is 6.5 mm above the injector boss that fits down into the extruder pinch roller pivot arm.
Infil at 20% grid is fine but may be made a little more dense if you want.
The funnel portion is very long so it reaches above my Y axis Chain as can be seen in the photo.
For the Red Top: In my case I used the "Change Filament in Print" described in the the PDF document to change from Yellow to Red about 12 layers below the top layer (0.6 mm) and got an easy to see funnel hole!

title: CrutziCam #1 - Raspberry Pi based Outdoor Surveillance Camera
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Created an outdoor Raspberry Pi based Surveillance camera. Using the following components:

  • Aluminium Case: Indexa KA 05
  • Mainboard: Raspberry Pi B+, 2 or 3
  • PSU: MeanWell RS-15-5 (5V, 3A)
  • Camera: Original RPi Camera, or WaveShare (IR Cut supported too)
  • Optional: PowerLine (HomePlugAV): TL-PA411 V2, short flat ethernet cable
  • Micro SD Card
  • 16 screws small 10 x 2, e.g. SPAX 4081020200102
  • 4 screws M3 x 5
  • Software: MotionEyeOS

Because of the high power consumption (RPi, Camera, IR LEDs & WLAN dongle), a 15W PSU gets connected directly via pins 2 (+5V) and 6 (GND) of the Pi. The RPi's USB port is limited to <2A iirc, which won't be sufficient for powering all components (e.g. the IR LEDs require ~3W each).

If the PowerLine (HomePlugAV) module shall be build-in, I've created a document howto extract the board from a consumer device: http://www.crutzi.info/hardware/components/tl-pa411-board

description.text:
I got fed up of trying to hollow out the various T800 designs on here, so thought I'd remix this one.

I've replaced the square LED's with 5mm round ones, which meant scaling the model down to 75% to make the eyes about 5.3mm

I've made the hole inside bigger to take a 250mAh LiPo battery, 22ohm resistor and switch and added a tunnel for the LED wires to reach into the hole, and filled in the holes at the back. The circuit uses 7mA.

I had planned to use OpenSCAD but the original model these are all based on is full of errors and OpenSCAD/FreeCAD couldn't render it to an STL - MeshMixer/MeshLab couldn't fix it either. So I used TinkerCAD.

author: fulvio1972

print_settings.Notes:: choose at least 4 perimeters for strength around the important bits

description.text:
Here we are again, this was a need derived project, i needed to stop the print bed constantly needing calibration. I've seen lots of frame braces for this printer and its brother the A8, however with out securing the printer down these only go part of the way. By analysing what was actually happening, ie lfting the corners of the printer and see it warp rather then lifting uniformly, i could see that the whole bottom of the frame needed braced.

Again this is a design from scratch project, i took meticulous measurements, printed and modified. I used vernier calipers and feeler gauges to get the exact height needed for MY A6, this should be the same for your A6, but definitely NOT for the A8, hence i put ANET A6 on the actual model.

I would definitely lay the model flat (rotate y 90 degrees) for printing, i certainly did.

Prints fine in Cura 2.3.1 or using Cura slicer from Repetier, print speed about 55mm/s, 0.2 layer height, 20% or higher infill, i also chose 4 perimeters to give the material around the screw holes more strength

20

Roue realisee en PLA

This is a basic RC car that is intended to be straightforward to understand, includes example code to control it via Wi-Fi, and uses centered drive wheels so that it can spin in place.

Suggested Build Instructions

Required materials
  1. 8x M2 16mm screws: Home Depot, AliExpress, AliExpress M2 Assortment
    • Substituting a length from 10mm to 20mm should work
  2. 4x 5/16" x 2" Fully Threaded Bolts: Home Depot
    • Bolt head doesn't matter. Longer is ok but results in axle sticking out from vehicle. Shorter down to 1.5" is ok but the idler wheels will be closer to the frame than the drive wheels.
  3. 12x 5/16" Lock Nut: Home Depot
    • 4 of these can be regular nuts (non locking) if it works out cheaper
  4. 2x MG946R Servos: AliExpress
    • These servos (or any digital servo roughly 1.60×0.78×1.69 in) should work as well: MG945, MG945R, MG946R, MG956R, MG995, MG995R, MG996R
  5. ESP8266 Microcontroller: Amazon, AliExpress
    Print the following
  6. 1x frame.stl
  7. 2x wheel_drive.stl
  8. 4x wheel_idler.stl

PLA or your preferred material is fine for the frame and idler wheels. A softer material like TPE/TPU is better for the drive wheels but PLA would still allow it to drive on flat surfaces.

Assembly
  1. Slide the 5/16" bolts into the holes on the frame so the threads are sticking out. Secure the bolts with two 5/16" lock nuts on the outside of the frame for each bolt. (The inner nut is just a spacer so the idler wheel is even with the drive wheel, you can use a plain nut for this or omit it entirely if you happen to have a shorter bolt.)
  2. Slide the idler wheels onto the threads. The idler wheels will be a tight fit on the threads at first so just spin them all the way in and slide them back and forth a bit and it will wear away enough material so the idler wheels can spin freely without climbing on the threads.
  3. Put a final lock nut on the threads to hold each idler wheel in place. The nuts should be tight enough to prevent the idler wheels from sliding side to side but loose enough to ensure they spin freely.
  4. Modify both servos so they can spin continuously. Here's an example guide: http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-hack-a-servo-for-continuous-rotation-Towe/
  5. Screw each servo to the frame. The servo should be placed so that its shaft is halfway between the idler wheels. The servo should include four screws that screw into the holes in the frame.
  6. Take the servo horn that looks like a plus. The drive wheel has a slot for the horn with holes to screw it in. You'll need to drill four of the servo horn holes slightly larger so the M2 screws can slide in...this should be the third hole from the inside, but to verify place the horn in the drive wheel slot to see which lines up.
  7. Place the horns in each drive wheel and screw them in with the M2x16mm screws. Make sure the horn is facing such that it will be able to slide onto the servo once screwed in.
  8. You can now mount the drive wheel onto the servo. Use a screwdriver through the hole in the drive wheel to screw it in.
Wi-Fi Control Setup
  1. Install the latest MicroPython firmware on your ESP8266: https://micropython.org/download
  2. Hook the brown/black wires of the servo to the ground pin on the ESP8266.
  3. Hook the red wires of the servo up to your 5V power source (on the nodemcu board this will be the Vin pin).
  4. Hook the orange/yellow wire from the left servo to GPIO5 (D1 on NodeMCU)
  5. Hook the orange/yellow wire from the right servo to GPIO4 (D2 on NodeMCU)
  6. Make sure wifi is configured on your ESP8266 so you can ping it
  7. Place servo.py on your ESP8266
  8. Place the attached main.py on your ESP8266.
  9. Power it up. If it works, you should be able to go the IP address of you ESP8266 in a browser and control your RC car.

Alternative Build Instructions

If printing the full frame is difficult because of your printer you can print 2xsubframe.stl instead of frame.stl. The instructions are very similar but instead of the 4x5/16" bolts you'll want 2x5/16"x12" (or shorter) threaded rods with 4x5/16" lock nuts.

author: BobbyBerk

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these tablet mounts on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width.

title: Adjustable tripod mount for tablet or smartphone

description.text:
This project allows mounting any tablet or smartphone onto any standard camera stand or tripod.

The mount is composed on two parts:

  • The base which is screwed onto the camera stand and which integrates the lower groove keeping the tablet in place.
  • The rod which contains the top groove fixing the tablet. It is inserted into the corresponding hole in the base and slid downwards until the tablet hold securely between top and bottom grooves.

A clamp screw at the rear of the base is used to secure the rod at the needed height. To hold the screw, a M3 screw nut is inserted into the corresponding cavity from inside the rod rail. An M3x10 wing screw (or just a normal M3 screw) is used to loosen or fasten the rod.

Three optional screw holes are also provided, one in the top part of the rod and two in the base, which can be used to attach springs or rubber bands to pull the rod downwards to hold the tablet by the spring force.

I found it useful to glue a little piece of soft rubber sheet

Besides the fully configurable OpenScad source file, I have included ready-to-print STL files for a larger and a smaller base, as well as rods with lengths 10cm, 13cm, 17cm and 20cm. Choose the rod length according to the width of your tablet or smartphone.

Supports:

No

Notes:

The provides STL files for the base contain a hole with an inner 1/4-20 UNC thread (the standard for camera mounts), using the thread implementation kindly provided by dkprojects.

The parameter gap in the OpenScad source contains the distance between fitting components (base/rod and base/mounting screw) and can be changed if needed.

I printed these tablet mounts on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width.

author: AndrewUsov

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the left holder is 2mm thick, the right one 3mm thick. The thickness of the right part is justified by the fact that the two "legs" that can be fixed to the alu extruders are quite thin so I wanted the material to be stronger. Note that the right holder wraps around the existing plastic holder that contain the USB and power ports.

description.text:
To avoid problems with curling on the perimeters of any model of medium difficulty, I decided to add two additional coolers (fans) that cool the filament immediately as it is laid. One cooler is not enough because I noticed that only one side of the model was without curling, the other side still developed it.

Unfortunately, adding the coolers narrows down the available horizontal work space, as the print head needs some clearance from the coolers. However, if one can live with that, give it a try.

I have used two 12cm Nidec TA450DC 12V/0.8A coolers, which are capable of delivering 220CFM, that is enough for anything. It is a bit overkill but I have not had any other smaller cooler at hands and I wanted to avoid the small 40 or 50mm coolers because I do not trust them.

The electronics I am using for regulation of the fan speed is available from the link:
http://www.pcbheaven.com/circuitpages/Simple_Linear_Fan_Controller/
It is the simplest linear regulator that can be built. I have used a C3039 transistor that I had at home but any NPN power-type can do the job.
With the circuit I am able to regulate the fans from ~7V to 12V, that allows quite a fine regulation even at lower RPMs. Sure it is not a fine PWM regulation but usable.

The third drawing is the case for this electronics that can be attached to the left cooler holder easily. Note that there are holes for a 40mm fan, that is needed to cool the power transistor at low fan RPMs.
Yes it seems a bit redundant, cooling the transistor that regulates the fans that are cooling the model :-) but believe me the dissipation at lower RPMs is quite high so the cooling of the transistor is indeed needed.

For mounting the holders to the alu extrusions I used the remaining 4mm screws and nuts that were provided by Anycubic.

All drawings were created in Sketchup, and these are included as well. Feel free to modify them if neccessary.

Printer:

Anycubic Kossel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Rotated the models in Slic3r and printed all parts standing.

The holes for fixing the parts to the two 2020 aluminium extrusion are a bit off, for the left cooler holder I used 38mm distance, that was not enough, for the right cooler holder I tried 40mm that was too much. So in both cases one have to drill a bit (few seconds matter) or modify the original draw. Sketchup files are available.

Note that the left holder is 2mm thick, the right one 3mm thick. The thickness of the right part is justified by the fact that the two "legs" that can be fixed to the alu extruders are quite thin so I wanted the material to be stronger. Note that the right holder wraps around the existing plastic holder that contain the USB and power ports.

author: Eron

title: FlashForge Creator Pro side blower fan bracket mount

description.text:
This is a replica of the bracket that is part of recent editions of the FlashForge Creator Pro and similar printers with a dual MK10 nozzle carriage. It is mounted on the left side of the extruder carriage, and supports both the blower fan and the fan duct. You need this if you want to install this type of fan and duct on an older printer that doesn't have this part, for instance if you want to install my dual duct.

It comes in two versions: one with larger holes in which three 5 mm deep metal M3 threaded inserts can be installed (see photo of the original, this is the recommended method as it makes a stronger part that won't wear out by repeated disassembly); and one with smaller holes that can accept M3 bolts directly (this is good if you quickly want something that does the job).

The Blender file is included to make it easier to adapt the model to specific needs.

For mounting, ideally you need:

  • two 6 mm countersunk M3 screws for the bracket itself,
  • two 20 mm socket, pan, or cheesehead M3 screws for the fan,
  • one 6 mm socket, pan, or cheesehead M3 screw for the fan duct.

However, you could probably modify the part to use similar screws you have lying around. Only the screws for the bracket itself must have an M3 thread.

For a perfect replica of the original part, find some cylindrical piece of whatever with a diameter of 2 mm and a length of less than 7 mm, and shove it in the tiny square-shaped hole in the model such that it sticks out 2 mm at the side where you mount the fan. This is optional, but provides a more secure mount for the fan duct.

If you need to buy the fan, this is what is mentioned on the one that came with my FFCP:
Ruiapple DC brushless blower
Model: DB5015HB24
DC 24V 0.10A

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Note: I haven't printed this yet since I have the original part. Let me know if you have any problems printing this.
You may want to use 3 perimeters so there is enough plastic around the mounting holes.
I would recommend ABS, as this will be attached to parts that become quite hot. If you want to compensate for ABS shrinkage and ensure the print has exact dimensions, you can scale it up to about 100.8%, although that's probably overkill for a part of this size.

As usual, it may be necessary to enlarge the holes a bit before you can install threaded inserts or screws, because very small holes like these tend to be printed too small by FDM printers. If you push brass inserts into the holes with a hot soldering iron, the exact size of the holes probably doesn't matter.

title: MM vertex / Arduino mount / fan mount

description.text:
This is a new arduino mount for MendelMax that replaces one of the top vertexes.
This can be fliped over to work on either the right or the left of the bot.
It is also designed so you can attach it to the underside of the extrusion if you prefer, this will lower the RAMPs board about 20mm reducing the profile of your bot a bit.

Print
mount fan
mount arduino
mount to bot in place of a vertex

author: Simonious

description.text: I've ordered a solder kit from Amazon. The kit is C51 4 bit clock (http://amzn.to/2kvSBIK). This kit haven't an enclosure. Also the clock haven't memory because there isn't a battery inside for memory. I've designed an enclosure that have a slot for 2 aaa battery, only for leave the setting in memory. Also the enclosure have a hole for USB cable. I leave opened the enclosure because the beautiful of this clock is the electronic board, and the components inside.

comments.text: My kids loved soldering their C51 kits up...

title: I Heart <3 Customizable Valentine (pick-a-weight) Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I Heart Customizable Valentine (pick-a-weight) Fidget Spinner

Customize it

  • easy to print
  • uses 1X 608 bearing (22x7) to spin
  • uses 2-6X 608 bearings, hex nuts (5/16", 3/8", 1/2", M8, M10, M12) or loose ball bearings (3/8", 1/2", 5/8") as weights

update 2017-09-29
Allow for ISO 4032 M10 (16mm) and M12 (18mm) hex nuts along with the old DIN 934 M10 (17mm) and M12 (19mm).
update 2017-04-18
added many more weight choices

Customize:

  • number of hearts
  • type of weight
  • edge roundness (radius)

Notes:

  • Customizer might time out when Radius > 0, but the Create Thing button still works
  • if a nut is loose in a PLA frame, dip nut in frame into hot water to shrink frame around nut
  • I use vise grips for easy hardware installation
  • See my collection of all my fidget spinner designs

description.text:
Needed somewhere to put my flight controller on my second VAS Banshee, so I built this.
it fits the on the bottom side of the airplane, just have to cut out the EEP buckout for the ESC.
Its close to but a bit aft of the CG on this plane. I used M3 screws from the underside of the of the print to attach short stand offs to hold the FC.
Look at the pictures and you can see how I cut the EPP. The Lid is held in place with #2x 1/2" screws from the hardware store. The sides are open to allow you to still attach a USB to the FC (and in my case, the FTDI to the on board OSD)
The FC is on here just so that I can run Sbus from my ImmersionRC EZUHF and so that I can Have an OSD with the GPS. I have yet to fly this airplane, but I have done a ton of flying with my other banshee, and it's a wonderful plane for flying. I always get the question, "how fast are you flying?" With this setup I will have an answer.
I printed in hatchbox bule ABS, because that's what I had loaded on the printer.
I do suggest that you either pre-install the FC or print a mock-up to hold the standoffs in the event that you slightly bend the box when you glue it in.
I also included the Sketchup 2016 file, if you want to modify or change the design, in that file I also have a stacker box for the GPS and FC chip, (which I printed, and it looks good, but I couldn't figure out where to install it on the airplane.)
The clack tubes you see installed in the airplane are carbon fiber arrow shafts that I used both as wire chases and as spars. This plane likes to tear in half right where the fuselage connects to the wings. so I put 2 arrow shafts down the length of the fuselage. i plan to run my camera wires through one and power to the camera and the VTX through the other.
