title: Robo3d Z-Carriage Drag Chain adaptor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you're like me, you probably installed the drag chain in one continuous loop from the print head down to the chassis, which inherently makes the drag chain get in the way of itself in certain position, even hitting the x-carriage limit switch occasionally. After all that work of running the wiring thru that chain and wire-tucking the exruder, who wants to go back and undo everything to remove a couple links or install some other drag chain adaptor that makes you run the wiring thru it (facepalm).

I present to you a simple way to change the direction on the drag chain by simply undoing the link at the desired location, stretch a tiny bit, then re-attach the links to their respective receivers. You do not have to remove the wires from the chain whatsoever! You will not even notice the wires, and this design allows for infinite adjustment until you get the desired lengths correct.

Please note this part is design with proper clearance for the Z-carriage protusion, so it will NOT friction fit! It was designed to use 3M VHB tape which allows the proper flex needed, and will not pop off on its own.

https://www.amazon.com/3M-Scotch-4910-VHB-Tape/dp/B00I4E4NE8/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1486316887&sr=8-2-spons&keywords=3m+vhb&psc=1

As a reminder, this part is designed to work with the ever so popular Uxcell 10x15mm drag chain:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0087ZSS0O/ref=sr_ph_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1486316961&sr=sr-1&keywords=uxcell+chain

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Bed Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a bracket system I developed for my Wanhao i3 and RaspBerry Pi camera that allows me to do frame captures and monitoring right from the bed.

The brackets are designed with a hinge that allow you to slip them around the front right (facing the printer) bed adjustment knob. The hinge provides support on the bottom plate that helps the part from flopping around as the bed moves.

Additionally, you should consider adding a smidge of adhesive at the end (inside depth wise of the bottom plate) of the support bracket on the underside of the runner that has the hinge. This will help greatly in keeping the bracket secure. I used a "Glue Dot" to adhere mine.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Be sure to add support around the hinge area as appropriate but don't go crazy with it.

Decide whether you want your mount on the side or the front of your bed and print the appropriate bracket.

You can print multiple arms depending on how you want to orient the camera. Two arms give you quite a bit of flexibility between angle and height.

Bracket Hinge Break Away & Assembly

Be gentle when breaking the hinge loose on the bracket and pulling it away from the bracket.

When installing the bracket you'll find it pretty easy to just slip the hinge/bracket around the front right adjustment knob on the bed. Just be a gentle when doing it and you'll be fine.

Design / CAD

Built using TinkerCAD with a caliper in hand for measuring.

Infill doesn't have to be more than 20% even with PLA for good performance. Heavier carriage will induce more 'ringing' artifacts, so no need to over do it.

https://youtu.be/lC0DSHMy9x8
https://youtu.be/GrBnLkITbCA

Features

  • Lightweight
  • Easy to print
    • No supports required
  • Multiple hotends supported
    • Chimera/Cyclops
    • Stock Tarantula hotend
    • E3D V6 Genuine/Clone
  • Quick-swap
    • switch hotends in seconds
  • Stock V-wheel or MGN12 rail
    • Makes it easy to start with V-wheel and upgrade to rail
  • Clean wiring solution
  • Integrated layer cooling
    • Using blower fan for higher pressure
    • Two options for fan placement
    • Swappable duct for experimenting with different designs
  • BLTouch mount
    • Nozzle offset kept same for various hotends - spacer available
  • No modification to stock frame or settings needed
  • Does not affect available print volume
  • Minimal vitamins needed
    • JST RCY 20AWG Prewired Connectors
    • Machine screws
    • Brass knurl inserts
    • 2.54 Pin Headers

UPDATE 1: Adding assembly illustrations
UPDATE 2: Adding version 1 files for carriage and E3D V6 mounts w/BLTouch
UPDATE 3: Adding version 1 files for E3D Chimera/Cyclops mount w/BLTouch
UPDATE 4: Adding drag chain support shelf and new simple layer fan duct
UPDATE 5: Adding carriage base version for MGN12 (H or C) linear guide (can also be used with stock v-wheel setup)

comments.text: I'm currently using this carriage.  I've also used the MSA, the LPA, and the Banholm Magnetic X-carriage.  So far, this one is my favorite.  I have a genuine E3d V6, and a separate E3d Volcano.  Swapping is great, but my favorite part is that it's easier for me to remove a hot end and clean it than with the other carriages.  Also, a problem I kept running into with the other ones, is that the connections would get damaged over time (all my fault--either JST male connectors that were soldered would break, or a dupont connector skinny wire would lose connection, etc.)  This one (so far) has prevented me from clumsily damaging the wiring as I swap.

comments.text:
You are welcome, happy to share..
1) The wiring harness to use depends, if you are using a BLTouch as well or not. Just pick ones with enough connectors for your wiring needs.
2) Chimera or Cyclops should work just fine
3) The regular wiring harness lid should just snap into place (there's a small tab keeping it secure). I would recommend using the drag-chain wiring harness upgrade. It makes for a much cleaner design in the end.
4) I just use the single fan duct in the rear as is included with the design, it works fine for me.
Good luck!

comments.text: Are the JST connectors rated for 40W? Those pins are awfully tiny. I think they're only good to 5 amps ==> 12V*5A=60W.
comments.author: jmpinc

comments.text:
So, 12v 40W heater should draw 3.3A and connectors handle that just fine.
They may not be ideal on paper, but in practice, I've been using this setup for a few months without problems. I've been monitoring the temp of that connection with the 2nd extruder thermistor I've wired up for this purpose. It does not get above 32-33C and usually hovers at under 30C. This is over hundreds of hours of printing using hotend temps up to 245C.
I got the idea from another popular extruder here (Tornado - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951/#comments) which uses 22AWG connectors and even those seems to work well.
comments.author: jmpinc

comments.text: It should be noted that these same connectors are used for RC LiPo applications where they are hit with 8A, even as much as 15A (though advised only for short periods).
comments.author: pin13

comments.text: Yeah, I saw that one and it got me wondering about it, and I saw this one and figured I'd ask. It's a nice setup and JST connectors are a lot more functional than crimp on bullet connectors. Been using them on my fans and thermistors but was reluctant to try them on my hotends. Given your experiences with them, I'll give them a try. Thanks!
comments.author: pin13

comments.text: No problem. Good luck!

comments.author: drshyegun

comments.text:
Great design!
What is the connector that connect the bl touch? You don't seem to have it listed in the parts list.
Also knurled inserts are m3x4mm? Will these work?
Look at this on eBay http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/302019239386
comments.author: drshyegun

comments.text:
Thanks! The knurled inserts you have linked will work perfectly, that's the kind I use.
As far as the BLTouch connector, it's a 2 row right angle 2.54mm pitch pin header. I bought a long strip (20 pins per row) and used my flush cutters to trim off 2x3 pin sections to use for the BLTouch connector. The profile of the plastic part is important so it can fit snugly into the housing I designed.
Example Datasheet for a good fit: http://www.mouser.com/ds/2/276/0901220128_PCB_HEADERS-151689.pdf
Example Datasheet for a poor fit: http://www.mouser.com/ds/2/1/ts2182-56782.pdf <-- not this kind
Here's some suppliers:
http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/pcb-headers/7979060/
http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Molex/90122-0128/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMs%252bGHln7q6pm1dHOBSb59bEaft3Tg%2fHkuw%3d
comments.author: drshyegun

Thanks and yes, it's ready.
I've been using the latest version for about a month now with Chimera and 3 different E3D V6 hotends. I'll be adding a couple of extra features including some better wiring management exiting the carriage with a drag-cable and a more ornate hotend 'lock', but nothing that will require other parts to be re-printed. Make sure you get the 20awg JST connectors for the heater cartridge wiring, otherwise gauge does not matter.
I'll post pics and video of it in action soon as well.

description.text:
Used on needle files with a 3mm diameter. Interference fit, must be pressed on or use a rubber mallet and a vise.
What I used and did;
Monoprice mini, .1325 layer height, 40% infill (not sure if it matters, I think it's 100% anyways because it's so small) 60mm/s. Took about 45 minutes for my slow machine, about 2g of material. Easy cheap handle. There are other files that look nicer than mine, but were going to take about 1.5 hours per handle and more material, so I just designed this quick and easy one.

I bought my needle files at Harbor Freight with a 20% off coupon for around $2.50, tax included. Came with 2 sets of 6.
UPDATE 2-6-17, when I printed one in ABS with a 0.0875 layer, the hole was slightly too large and no longer an interference fit.

No need for a raft or brim, just use a skirt to make sure it's extruding fully before it starts the first layer.
